III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12313 (2) Behavior support policy; life-saving
Section intervention.
Description
(2) An agency shall ensure that methods of behavior
management for a foster child are positive and consistent,
based on each foster child’s needs, stage of development,
and behavior, and promote self-control, self-esteem, and
independence. Problems of child training shall be handled
with sympathy and understanding.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation It has been reported that a foster family is using a level system for
discipline with a female youth. In addition, the foster family is
using seclusion with another youth in the home.
Investigation Youth A’s case file was reviewed. The file indicated
that Youth A, age 14, was placed in the foster on 12/22/22. She
was replaced on 8/25/23. Prior, Youth A had several placements
that included being in a detention facility 3 times. Her file
indicated that she is diagnosed with major depression disorder
and attention deficit hyperactivity disorder.
Complainant was interviewed on 7/21/23, regarding this
allegation. It was reported that Hillsdale was completing an SER
on the foster family but wasn’t citing the family for the discipline
because the agency did not feel the rules prohibit the use of the
foster parents’ behavior management plan. The details provided
were that the youth is required to wear a “uniform”. She has
multiple plain shirts, but only one pair of pants that are washed
every night. Youth A is not allowed to speak to any of the children
in the home, the only people she can speak to are the foster
parents. In order for Youth A to speak, she must raise her hand.
Youth A is required to sit in a specific chair for the day. The
complainant reported the family specifically stated they are not
isolating the youth because she is allowed to be around them,
(Foster parents), they call it a separation. It was reported this
goes on indefinitely until Youth A follows the rules enough to be
moved up to the next level. The Complainant said the foster
parents stated they received the policy from the local youth home.
2

Program Manager contacted this Consultant on 7/26/23 via
email and reported that she was confused regarding the allegation
directly on the agency. She reported there is currently a special
evaluation newly assigned on the foster home as well as a DHHS
complaint regarding the allegation with the foster parents which is
still in the investigation process. The Program Manager reported
her agency has already determined that there will be findings of
non-compliance in the home, but they are also continuing to
investigate concerns.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed on 7/26/23 via video
conference with the Licensing Supervisor and Program
Manager. The Foster Care Worker reported that Youth A was
placed in the foster home on 12/22/22. She reported other
children were placed in the home at the time of the complaint but
have sense been replaced. She reported the foster home was
placed on hold for placements after the second allegations were
made against the family. They and will remain on hold pending the
completion of DHHS investigation and the agency special
investigation evaluation. The foster care worker reported that the
foster parents’ have been providing care for Youth A since
December 2022. She said in June 2023 after significant
behavioral issues foster parents decided to implement a similar
structured plan for their home. This plan was a level system
ranging from the most restrictive being level 0 to the least
restrictive being level 4. It was during the 48 hours of being on
level 0 that Youth A was given very few freedoms. Youth A was
made to wear a uniform which consisted of one pair of pants
(washed nightly) and a few plain colored shirts to choose from.
Youth A was also given no snacks or desserts during this time,
she was not allowed to speak to anyone in the home except for
the foster parents by raising her hand and waiting to be called on.
The Foster Care Worker said Youth A was made to sit in a chair
when she was not completing chores, exercising, showering, or
completing other tasks allowed by the foster parents. The foster
parents explained the level system was not meant to harm the
child but instead they were hoping that because a similar
structured plan worked so well while she was in detention, this
same routine would help her to be successful outside of the
detention center. The Foster Care Worker said the foster parents
expressed their love for Youth A and reported they only wanted
what is best for her. She said the foster parents was hoping Youth
A would learn through the loss of freedoms/privileges she would
be successful. The Foster Care worker reported at no time was
she aware of another youth in the home being place on seclusion.
3

The Foster Care Worker reported she was also unaware that the
family was using a level system with Youth A prior to receiving the
complaint. The Licensing Worker and Program Manager reported
the same information.
Foster Care Worker was interviewed again on 8/11/23 via
video conference. She provided the following timeline for this
allegation pertaining to Youth A.
12/22/2022- Youth A placed in the foster parent’ home.
05/23/2023- Youth A placed in Hillsdale County Youth Home
06/20/2023- Youth A returned to the foster parent’ home.
07/13/2023- Youth A placed in Hillsdale County Youth Home
07/14/2023- Youth A placed in Maurice Spears detention center.
07/14/2023- CI complaint/DHHS not assigned: It was reported that
the foster dad hurts Youth B bad when he gets in trouble. It was
reported that foster dad uses a closed fist and an open hand.
Foster dad also will put his middle finger up to the child. It was
clarified the foster dad threatens punishment by making gestures
by making a closed fist and a open hand, but he does not strike or
hit Youth B. It is unknown when this last happened. On 7/11/2023,
Youth B has a scrape on the left side of his nose when his sister
scratched him with her hand or a toy. Youth B does currently have
a fading black eye from an incident that took place on 7/13/2023
where he and another child in the home were playing on a sled
and Youth B fell.
07/14/2023- Social work contact between FC worker and Youth A
while Youth A was placed in Maurice Spears. Youth A reports to
the caseworker a level system is being used in the foster parent’
home and she does not want to return to the home.
07/17/2023- Youth A returned to the foster parent’ home.
07/19/2023- CI complaint/DHHS not assigned: Foster dad is using
a level system of punishment for Youth A. She is always on a level
0. This means she must wear a specific outfit at all times, stay
seated in a chair, and not speak to anyone else in the home. She
must raise her hand to talk. Youth A is being isolated and
secluded in a room. Foster dad tries to stand in her way so she
cannot leave. Youth A will leave the home without permission to
go for walks to calm down. Foster dad then calls Youth A’s
probation officer and reports her for not following the rules. Youth
A has been sent to the youth home several times recently and as
soon as Youth A comes to the foster home, the foster dad gets
her re-lodged the same day.
In the CI complaint it was alleged that another foster youth in the
home t is being isolated/secluded away from the other children as
well. There are concerns that foster dad is running his foster home
4

as a residential facility including hiring staff and using a level
system, restraints, and isolating/secluding youth.
07/19/2023- New allegations added to SE already imitated on
07/17/2023.
07/20/2023- Home visit and interviews completed with foster
parents’ and Youth A.
07/25/2023- PCU meeting to discuss initial and new allegations
made against the foster parent’s family. Due to licensing
confirming the level system is being used it was determined
DHHS should be included in the investigation.
07/26/2023- DHHS assigned.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED:
Youth A’s updated service plan dated 2/17/23:
• The foster care worker reported a private conversation with
Youth A. Youth A reported she loves living with the foster
family and ask if she could be adopted by the foster
parents. No other concerns were noted.
DHHS report dated 9/6/23:
• The report states that Youth A therapist reported that Youth
A does not understand boundaries and when left to her
own choices she ultimately makes a bad one, and when
called out on it, Youth A becomes defensive and verbally or
physically and lashes out on whoever is in her path. It is
noted in this report that the therapist reported that the foster
parents’ wants the best for the children placed in their
home and that they have received limited support and there
are no services outside of services being provided by
juvenile court.
• In this report, Youth A reported to the worker that she feels
safe in the foster home and there was nothing in the home
that she does not like. In regard to the level system, Youth
A said the family is trying something new.
• It was noted in this report that Youth A probation office
reported Youth A needs structure and routine and
expressed that the foster dad has done what has been
asked of him thus far relating to Youth A’s needs.
• The DHHS recommendation stated there was insufficient
evidence that the “level system” (behavior plan) created by
the foster family resulted in harm or threatened harm to
Youth A.
Agency special evaluation report dated 9/14/23:
5

• The agency found the foster parents in non-compliance
with Rules 400.9201 (1)(b)(ii) Foster home
applicant/licensee qualification; central registry check,
400.9404 (1) Behavior management, 400.9404 (3)
Behavior management.
Agency special evaluation CAP dated 8/29/23:
• This CAP was signed by the foster parents on 8/29/23.
• The CAP states the foster parents will complete all required
training recommended by the department.
• The licensees will be provided with a list of required training
to be completed.
• The CAP will be monitored by the assigned license
specialist until November 1, 2023, to ensure compliance of
training hour and compliance with requirements agreed
upon in the CAP.
Analysis Based on documentation, agency special evaluation and findings,
DHHS investigation and interviews with staff, it is determined that
the agency had initiated a special evaluation on the foster home
on 7/17/23. New allegations were presented on 7/19/23 whereby
the agency was informed about the level system and new
allegations were added and the allegations were assigned to a
DHHS worker. The agency was aware of these allegations and
had initiated a special investigation on the foster home prior to
DCWL receiving a complaint on the agency on 7/21/2023. It is
determined that the agency is not in violation with this rule.
Conclusion VIOLATION NOT ESTABLISH
6

IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that Hillsdale County DHHS current
license status be continued.
